column1: Social relations, physical activity, and well-being in older adults.
column2: E. McAuley, B. Blissmer, D. Marquez, G. Jerome, A. Kramer, J. Katula
column8: Randomized controlled trial; Longitudinal study; Intervention study
column9:
- Total sample size: 174
- Age range or mean age: Mean age = 65.5 years
- Gender distribution: Not reported
- Physical activity level at baseline: Formerly sedentary
- Inclusion/exclusion criteria: Not reported
column10:
- Type of physical activity: Aerobic activity group, Stretching and toning group
- Frequency (times per week): Not fully specified
- Duration of each session: Not fully specified
- Total intervention period: 12-month period
- Intensity: Not fully specified
column11: Measurement method not clearly specified (the abstract does not provide details on the specific tool or instrument used to measure life satisfaction, nor does it specify the timing or quantification method)
column12: No significant improvement observed (the abstract does not provide specific time points or statistical details for improvements in life satisfaction)
column13:
- Total study follow-up period: 12 months
- Number and timing of follow-up assessments: At least one follow-up assessment at 6 months
column14:
- "A randomized controlled trial was conducted to examine: (a) the effect of two physical activity modes on changes in subjective well-being (SWB) over the course of a 12-month period in older, formerly sedentary adults (N = 174, M age = 65.5 years) and (b) the role played by physical activity participation and social support in changes in SWB over time."
  - "Participants were randomized into either an aerobic activity group or a stretching and toning group."
  - "Structural equation modeling was employed to conduct multiple sample latent growth curve analyses of individual growth in measures of SWB (happiness, satisfaction with life, and loneliness) over time."
column16:
- The abstract explicitly states that the study is a "randomized controlled trial," which is a type of study design where participants are randomly assigned to different groups to compare outcomes.
- The mention of participants being "randomized into either an aerobic activity group or a stretching and toning group" further supports the randomized controlled trial design, as it involves random assignment to different intervention groups.
- The use of "structural equation modeling" and "latent growth curve analyses" suggests a longitudinal component, as these methods are typically used to analyze changes over time.
- The study involves an intervention, as it examines the effects of different physical activity modes on subjective well-being, which aligns with the characteristics of an intervention study.
column17:
- "A randomized controlled trial was conducted to examine: (a) the effect of two physical activity modes on changes in subjective well-being (SWB) over the course of a 12-month period in older, formerly sedentary adults (N = 174, M age = 65.5 years)"
  - "Participants were randomized into either an aerobic activity group or a stretching and toning group."
column19:
- The total sample size is explicitly mentioned as "N = 174."
- The mean age of the participants is given as "M age = 65.5 years."
- The abstract describes the participants as "older, formerly sedentary adults," indicating their physical activity level at baseline.
- There is no mention of gender distribution or specific inclusion/exclusion criteria in the abstract.
column20:
- "Participants were randomized into either an aerobic activity group or a stretching and toning group."
  - "A curvilinear growth pattern was revealed with well-being significantly improving over the course of the intervention followed by significant declines at the 6-month follow-up."
  - "Improvements in social relations and exercise frequency also helped to buffer the declines in satisfaction with life at follow-up."
column22:
- The abstract mentions two types of physical activity interventions: an aerobic activity group and a stretching and toning group. This provides the type of physical activity.
- The abstract does not specify the frequency (times per week) or duration of each session for either group. This information is not provided in the abstract.
- The total intervention period is mentioned as a "12-month period," which indicates the duration of the study but not the specific intervention period.
- The intensity of the physical activity is not specified in the abstract.
- The abstract does not provide specific units or quantitative descriptions for frequency, duration, or intensity, so these details are not fully specified.
column23:
- "Structural equation modeling was employed to conduct multiple sample latent growth curve analyses of individual growth in measures of SWB (happiness, satisfaction with life, and loneliness) over time."
  - "Improvements in social relations and exercise frequency also helped to buffer the declines in satisfaction with life at follow-up."
  - "Subsequent structural analyses were conducted showing that frequency of exercise participation was a significant predictor of improvement in satisfaction with life, whereas social relations were related to increases in satisfaction with life and reductions in loneliness."
  - "A curvilinear growth pattern was revealed with well-being significantly improving over the course of the intervention followed by significant declines at the 6-month follow-up."
  - "A randomized controlled trial was conducted to examine: (a) the effect of two physical activity modes on changes in subjective well-being (SWB) over the course of a 12-month period in older, formerly sedentary adults (N = 174, M age = 65.5 years) and (b) the role played by physical activity participation and social support in changes in SWB over time."
column25:
- The abstract mentions that the study examined changes in subjective well-being (SWB) over a 12-month period, which includes satisfaction with life as a component of SWB.
- It specifies that structural equation modeling was used to analyze growth in measures of SWB, including satisfaction with life, over time.
- The abstract indicates that there was a curvilinear growth pattern in well-being, with improvements followed by declines at the 6-month follow-up, suggesting that measurements were taken at least at baseline and at the 6-month follow-up.
- However, the abstract does not specify the exact tool or instrument used to measure life satisfaction, nor does it provide details on how life satisfaction was quantified (e.g., scale or scoring method).
column26:
- "Subsequent structural analyses were conducted showing that frequency of exercise participation was a significant predictor of improvement in satisfaction with life, whereas social relations were related to increases in satisfaction with life and reductions in loneliness."
  - "A curvilinear growth pattern was revealed with well-being significantly improving over the course of the intervention followed by significant declines at the 6-month follow-up."
  - "Improvements in social relations and exercise frequency also helped to buffer the declines in satisfaction with life at follow-up."
column28:
- The abstract mentions a "curvilinear growth pattern" with well-being improving over the course of the intervention, which suggests that there is an improvement in life satisfaction at some point during the study.
- The improvement in well-being is noted to occur "over the course of the intervention," which implies that the improvement happens during the 12-month period of the study.
- The abstract does not specify the exact time point at which the improvement in life satisfaction is first observed, nor does it provide specific statistical significance or magnitude of improvement.
- The mention of "significant declines at the 6-month follow-up" suggests that any improvements in life satisfaction likely occurred before this point, but again, no specific time point is provided.
- The abstract does not provide exact p-values or effect sizes for the improvement in life satisfaction, nor does it specify the statistical significance of the change.
column29:
- "A curvilinear growth pattern was revealed with well-being significantly improving over the course of the intervention followed by significant declines at the 6-month follow-up."
  - "A randomized controlled trial was conducted to examine: (a) the effect of two physical activity modes on changes in subjective well-being (SWB) over the course of a 12-month period in older, formerly sedentary adults"
column31:
- The abstract mentions that the study was conducted over a "12-month period," which indicates the total duration of the study.
- The phrase "significant declines at the 6-month follow-up" suggests that there was at least one follow-up assessment at 6 months after the intervention began.
- The abstract does not specify if there were additional follow-up assessments beyond the 6-month point, nor does it mention any variations in follow-up periods between participant groups.

column1: The effect of a four-week fitness program on satisfaction with health and life
column2: P. Wicker, D. Coates, C. Breuer
column8: Intervention study; Longitudinal study; Observational study
column9:
- Total sample size: 10,386
- Age range or mean age: mean age = 46.4
- Gender distribution: 69.9% female
- Physical activity level at baseline: Not reported
- Inclusion/exclusion criteria: Not reported
column10:
- Type of physical activity: Six strength exercises
- Frequency: Two times per week
- Duration of each session: 30 minutes
- Total intervention period: 4 weeks
- Intensity: Not fully specified
column11: Measurement method not clearly specified (the abstract does not provide details on the specific tool, timing, or quantification method for life satisfaction measurement)
column12:
- Earliest time point showing statistically significant improvement in life satisfaction: After 4 weeks
- Magnitude of improvement: Not quantified
- Statistical significance of the change: Significant (p-value not specified)
column13: Total study follow-up period: 4 weeks; Number and timing of follow-up assessments: Post-survey at the end of the 4-week program
column14:
- "The threefold study design comprised a physical entry test accompanied by a pre-survey, a fitness program (six strength exercises; two times 30 min per week over a 4-week period), and an exit test accompanied by a post-survey."
  - "Regression analysis was used to isolate the effect of the fitness program while controlling for gender, age, age squared, education, income, motivation, physical performance, month, and state."
  - "Participants (69.9 % female; mean age = 46.4; mean BMI = 25.9; N = 10,386) self-selected in the program in 316 fitness clubs across Germany."
column16:
- The study involves a "threefold study design" which includes a pre-survey, a fitness program, and a post-survey. This suggests a structured intervention with measurements before and after the intervention, which is characteristic of an intervention study.
- The participants "self-selected" into the program, which indicates that the study is not a randomized controlled trial since participants were not randomly assigned to groups.
- The use of regression analysis to control for various factors suggests an attempt to isolate the effect of the intervention, which is typical in observational studies where confounding variables need to be controlled.
- The study measures changes over time (from pre-survey to post-survey), which aligns with a longitudinal study design.
- The abstract does not mention randomization or control groups, which rules out a randomized controlled trial.
column17:
- "Participants (69.9 % female; mean age = 46.4; mean BMI = 25.9; N = 10,386) self-selected in the program in 316 fitness clubs across Germany."
  - "The reported level of satisfaction with life and health was significantly higher after participation in the 4-week fitness program."
  - "Physical performance improved significantly (p < 0.001)."
  - "Regression analysis was used to isolate the effect of the fitness program while controlling for gender, age, age squared, education, income, motivation, physical performance, month, and state."

column1: The effects of physical activity on sleep quality, job satisfaction, and quality of life in office workers
column2: S. S. Arslan, I. Alemdaroğlu, A. Karaduman, Ö. Yılmaz
column9:
- Total sample size: 109
- Age range or mean age: Not reported
- Gender distribution: Not reported
- Physical activity level at baseline: Group I: regular physical activity for at least eight weeks; Group II: no regular physical activity
- Inclusion/exclusion criteria: Not reported
column10:
- Type of physical activity: Not fully specified
- Frequency (times per week): Not fully specified
- Duration of each session: Not fully specified
- Total intervention period: At least eight weeks
- Intensity: Not fully specified
column11:
- Specific tool/instrument used to measure life satisfaction: World Health Organization Quality-of-Life-Scale (WHOQOL-BREF)
- Timing of measurements: Measurement method not clearly specified
- How life satisfaction was quantified: Measurement method not clearly specified
column12: No significant improvement observed (the abstract does not provide specific time points or magnitudes of improvement for life satisfaction)
column13: Follow-up duration not specified (the abstract only mentions the duration of physical activity for Group I but does not specify the total study follow-up period or the timing of follow-up assessments)
column14:
- "Sleep quality, job satisfaction, and quality of life were assessed using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, the Minnesota Job Satisfaction Scale, and the World Health Organization Quality-of-Life-Scale (WHOQOL-BREF), respectively."
  - "There were two groups; Group I did regular physical activity for at least eight weeks, and Group II did no regular physical activity."
  - "A convenience sample of office workers from administrative staff of a university was included."
column16:
- The study uses a "convenience sample," which suggests an observational approach rather than a randomized controlled trial.
- The presence of two groups (one with regular physical activity and one without) indicates a comparative element, which is common in observational studies.
- The study assesses outcomes over a period (at least eight weeks), which could imply a longitudinal aspect, but the abstract does not explicitly state that the study followed participants over time to observe changes.
- The study does not mention any intervention or manipulation of variables by the researchers, which would be characteristic of an intervention study.
- The abstract does not provide explicit details about the study design, such as whether it was randomized or controlled, but the use of a convenience sample and comparison between groups suggests an observational study.
column17:
- "A convenience sample of office workers from administrative staff of a university was included."
  - "Group I did regular physical activity for at least eight weeks, and Group II did no regular physical activity."
  - "No significant differences were found between groups in terms of age, height, weight, and the period of time worked (p > 0.05)."
  - "Group I included 59 individuals and Group II 50 individuals."
column19:

- "Sleep quality, job satisfaction, and quality of life were assessed using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, the Minnesota Job Satisfaction Scale, and the World Health Organization Quality-of-Life-Scale (WHOQOL-BREF), respectively."
  - "Regular physical activity could increase job satisfaction and quality of life for office workers."
  - "All subscales of the WHOQOL-BREF for Group I was higher than Group II (p < 0.05)."

  - "Regular physical activity could increase job satisfaction and quality of life for office workers."
  - "All subscales of the WHOQOL-BREF for Group I was higher than Group II (p < 0.05)."
  - "The aim of this study was to determine the effects of physical activity on sleep quality, job satisfaction, and quality of life in office workers."

- The WHOQOL-BREF subscales, which measure quality of life, were also higher in Group I compared to Group II with a statistical significance of p < 0.05, indicating an improvement in quality of life.
- However, the abstract does not specify the exact time point at which these improvements were observed, nor does it provide a magnitude of improvement or specific effect sizes.

column1: Elevating Subjective Well-Being Through Physical Exercises: An Intervention Study
column2: Katarzyna Iwon, Julia Skibinska, Dorota Jasielska, Sonia Kalwarczyk
column8: Longitudinal study; Intervention study; Observational study
column9:
- Total sample size: 217
- Age range: 18 to 64 years; Mean age: 29.57 years
- Gender distribution: Women: 57.1%, Men: 41.9%, Other/Not reported: 1%
- Physical activity level at baseline: Active people: ≥3 times/week, ≥30 minutes/session; Beginners: Not active or irregularly active; Inactive people: <1 time/week
- Inclusion/exclusion criteria: Excluded those under 18, those exercising 1-2 times/week, and those not planning to exercise in the following month
column10:
- Type of physical activity: Participation in classes organized by fitness clubs or gyms
- Frequency: Active people - at least three times a week; Beginners - at least twice a week
- Duration of each session: Minimum of 30 minutes
- Total intervention period: 4 weeks
- Intensity: Not fully specified
column11:
- Specific tool/instrument used to measure life satisfaction: Satisfaction With Life Scale (SWLS)
- Timing of measurements: Baseline (T1) and after 4 weeks (T2)
- How life satisfaction was quantified: Seven-point Likert scale (from 1 - "Definitely disagree" to 7 - "Definitely agree")
column12:
- Earliest time point showing statistically significant improvement in life satisfaction: 4 weeks
- Magnitude of improvement: Mean increased from 4.80 to 5.12
- Statistical significance of the change: p < 0.05 (specifically, p = 0.036)
column13:
- Total study follow-up period: 2 months
- Number and timing of follow-up assessments: 1 follow-up assessment after 4 weeks
column14:
- "In the current study, we aimed to examine whether regular activity initiation can impact happiness, life satisfaction, and self-esteem 4 weeks later."
  - "The study showed a strong relationship between subjective well-being and physical activity."
  - "In this study, we investigate whether commencing physical activity positively affects happiness, life satisfaction, and self-esteem after 4 weeks of exercising."
  - "Conducting a study in a naturalistic design supports the practical relevance of the research for designing future interventions that can elevate various aspects of subjective well-being."
  - "The study lasted over 2 months, from January 11 to March 19, 2019."
  - "Furthermore, to investigate the impact of exercise on well-being, we conducted our measures twice: at the moment of initiation for Group 2 and 4 weeks later."
  - "The study was conducted at the beginning of January, taking into consideration that starting to exercise is a popular New Year's resolution."
column16:
- The study involves examining the impact of physical activity on subjective well-being over a period of time, which suggests a longitudinal component.
- The study is described as being conducted in a "naturalistic design," which implies an observational study design rather than a controlled trial.
- The participants are divided into groups based on their physical activity levels, and measures are taken at two points in time, indicating a longitudinal study design.
- The study aims to investigate the effects of commencing physical activity, which aligns with an intervention study design.
- The study does not mention randomization or control groups, which rules out a randomized controlled trial.
column17:
- "The sample (N = 217, 124 women) was divided into three groups based on level of physical activity (active people, beginners, and inactive people)."
  - "The respondents' ages ranged from 18 to 64 years (M = 29.57, SD = 9.11)."
  - "The average age in the studied groups was as follows -active people (M = 30.51, SD = 9.40), beginners (M = 26.97, SD = 6.59), and inactive people (M = 30.95, SD = 10.30)."
  - "A total of 57.1% of the respondents were women, 41.9% were men, and 1% were people who did not identify with either of these genders or did not answer the question."
  - "The participants were divided into three groups based on their frequency of physical activity: active people (74 participants), beginners (67 participants), and inactive people (76 participants)."
  - "The sample consisted of 295 people, although 78 were later excluded either because: (1) people under the age of 18; (2) people who declared exercising once or twice a week (we decided to exclude this group in order to compare active persons with inactive ones); and (3) people who exercised before the study but did not plan to exercise in the following month at the gym or fitness club because they did not meet our criteria and did not qualify for any of our groups."
column19:
- The total sample size is explicitly mentioned as 217 participants.
- The age range is provided as 18 to 64 years, with a mean age of 29.57 years.
- Gender distribution is detailed: 57.1% women, 41.9% men, and 1% not identifying with either gender or not answering.
- Physical activity levels at baseline are described: active people exercised at least three times a week for at least 30 minutes per session, beginners had not been active or were irregularly active and planned to start, and inactive people did not engage in physical activity or did so less than once a week.
- Inclusion/exclusion criteria are detailed: excluded were those under 18, those exercising once or twice a week, and those who did not plan to exercise in the following month.
column20:
- "The participants were divided into three groups based on their frequency of physical activity: active people (74 participants), beginners (67 participants), and inactive people (76 participants)."
  - "Active people were considered those who had been doing physical activity for at least 3 months, on average, three times a week or more, for a minimum of 30 min in one exercise session."
  - "Beginners were people who had not been doing physical activity or had been doing it irregularly in the past 3 months (on average less than once a week) and expressed a willingness to start physical activity in a fitness club or gym at least twice a week for a month."
  - "The group of active people consisted of people who were physically active at least three times a week during the 3 months before and during the study."
  - "The group of beginners consisted of people who exercised at least twice a week during the research yet had not participated in physical activity or had exercised less than once a week during the 3 months before starting the study."
  - "The study lasted over 2 months, from January 11 to March 19, 2019."
  - "Four weeks after completing the first survey, participants received at the provided email address a link to an online survey (second survey)."
  - "The study was conducted at the beginning of January, taking into consideration that starting to exercise is a popular New Year's resolution."
column22:
- The study involved three groups: active people, beginners, and inactive people.
- Active people were those who had been physically active for at least 3 months, exercising at least three times a week for a minimum of 30 minutes per session.
- Beginners were those who had not been regularly active but started exercising at least twice a week for a month.
- The total intervention period for the study was approximately 2 months, but the specific intervention period for physical activity was 4 weeks.
- The intensity of the physical activity is not fully specified in terms of specific exercises or intensity levels, but it is mentioned that it involved participation in classes organized by fitness clubs or gyms.
column23:
- "We used the Satisfaction With Life Scale (SWLS; Diener et al., 1985; Polish translation: Jankowski, 2015) , which assesses a person's general sense of satisfaction with their quality of life."
  - "It contains five statements (such as "I am satisfied with my life"). Participants answer using a seven-point Likert scale (from 1 -"Definitely disagree, " to 7 -"Definitely agree")."
  - "The reliability of the scale was good: α = 0.830 for the first measurement and α = 0.894 for the second."
  - "The analysis included 95 people consisting of adult participants and those who met the conditions for being either active, a beginner or inactive."
  - "The study lasted over 2 months, from January 11 to March 19, 2019."
  - "Four weeks after completing the first survey, participants received at the provided email address a link to an online survey (second survey)."
  - "The second measurement (T2) on a sample of 95 people showed stronger relationships between the studied variables."
  - "The simple effect of time (T1, T2) on the level of life satisfaction turned out to be statistically significant F(1, 92) = 7.29, p = 0.008."
  - "The effect of the interaction of the group (active people/ beginners/inactive people) and time on the level of life satisfaction was statistically insignificant F(2, 92) = 0.77, p = 0.465."
column25:
- The specific tool used to measure life satisfaction is the Satisfaction With Life Scale (SWLS).
- The SWLS is a widely recognized instrument for assessing life satisfaction, and it was used in both the baseline (T1) and follow-up (T2) measurements.
- The timing of measurements was at baseline (T1) and after 4 weeks (T2).
- Life satisfaction was quantified using a seven-point Likert scale, where participants answered from 1 ("Definitely disagree") to 7 ("Definitely agree").
- The reliability of the scale was reported as good for both measurements, indicating that it is a reliable tool for measuring life satisfaction.
- The study involved two measurement points: baseline and after 4 weeks, which aligns with the timing of the measurements.
column26:
- "The study showed a strong relationship between subjective well-being and physical activity."
  - "Furthermore, after 4 weeks of exercising, beginners revealed greater life satisfaction and happiness compared to the baseline."
  - "A Student's t test for dependent samples was used to verify whether commencing exercise leads to a higher level of happiness (H4). As Table 2 shows, after 4 weeks of physical activity, the beginners' average levels of life satisfaction and sense of happiness increased above the baseline (p < 0.05)."
  - "The simple effect of time (T1, T2) on the level of life satisfaction turned out to be statistically significant F(1, 92) = 7.29, p = 0.008."
  - "The effect of the interaction of the group (active people/ beginners/inactive people) and time on the level of life satisfaction was statistically insignificant F(2, 92) = 0.77, p = 0.465."
  - "The average intensity of life satisfaction and sense of happiness after 4 weeks of exercise became higher than the baseline."
  - "The study of Wicker et al. (2015) showed a similar effect on life satisfaction after a 4-week fitness program."
column28:
- The study found a significant improvement in life satisfaction after 4 weeks of physical activity, as indicated by the increase in life satisfaction among beginners compared to their baseline levels.
- The statistical significance of this change is supported by a p-value of less than 0.05, as mentioned in the context of the Student's t test for dependent samples.
- The improvement in life satisfaction is quantified in Table 2, which shows an increase from a mean of 4.80 to 5.12, with a p-value of 0.036 and an effect size (d) of 0.38.
- The simple effect of time on life satisfaction was statistically significant, with an F-value of 7.29 and a p-value of 0.008, indicating a significant change over time.
- The interaction effect between group and time was not significant, but this does not negate the overall improvement observed in life satisfaction.
column29:
- "The study lasted over 2 months, from January 11 to March 19, 2019."
  - "To assess whether the obtained effect is persistent and exercising leads to changes in well-being, we decided to re-measure all the variables after 4 weeks."
  - "The analysis included 95 people consisting of adult participants and those who met the conditions for being either active, a beginner or inactive."
  - "Only 140 participants completed the second questionnaire."
  - "Four weeks after completing the first survey, participants received at the provided email address a link to an online survey (second survey)."
column31:
- The study duration is explicitly mentioned as lasting over 2 months, which provides a general timeframe for the study.
- The follow-up assessment is clearly stated to occur 4 weeks after the initial survey, indicating a specific follow-up duration.
- The mention of a "second survey" sent 4 weeks after the first survey confirms that there is a follow-up assessment at this time point.
- The analysis of 95 participants who completed both surveys further supports the 4-week follow-up duration.

column1: Physical activity enhances long-term quality of life in older adults: Efficacy, esteem, and affective influences
column2: S. Elavsky, E. McAuley, R. Motl, James F. Konopack, D. Marquez, Liang Hu, G. Jerome, E. Diener
column9:
- Total sample size: 174
- Age range or mean age: Mean age = 66.7 years
- Gender distribution: Not reported
- Physical activity level at baseline: Not reported
- Inclusion/exclusion criteria: Not reported
column10:
- Type of physical activity: Not fully specified
- Frequency (times per week): Not fully specified
- Duration of each session: Not fully specified
- Total intervention period: 6 months
- Intensity (if specified): Not fully specified
column11: Measurement method not clearly specified (the abstract does not specify the exact tool or instrument used to measure life satisfaction, nor does it provide details on the scale or scoring method)
column12:
- Earliest time point showing statistically significant improvement in life satisfaction: 1 year
- Magnitude of improvement: Not mentioned
- Statistical significance of the change: Not mentioned
column13:
- Total study follow-up period: 4 years
- Number and timing of follow-up assessments: 1 year and 5 years after enrollment
column14: - "Participants (N = 174, M age = 66.7 years) completed a battery of psychosocial measures at 1 and 5 years following enrollment in a 6-month randomized controlled exercise trial.Results:"
column16:
- The abstract explicitly mentions that the study involved a "6-month randomized controlled exercise trial." This indicates that the study design includes elements of a randomized controlled trial (RCT), as it involves random assignment of participants to different conditions.
- The study also involved measurements at two time points: 1 year and 5 years after enrollment. This suggests a longitudinal component, as the study tracks changes over time.
- The combination of a randomized controlled trial with longitudinal measurements indicates that the study design is both a randomized controlled trial and a longitudinal study.
column17:
- "Participants (N = 174, M age = 66.7 years)"
  - "completed a battery of psychosocial measures at 1 and 5 years following enrollment in a 6-month randomized controlled exercise trial.Results:"
column19:
- The total sample size is explicitly mentioned as "N = 174."
- The mean age of the participants is given as "M age = 66.7 years."
- There is no mention of the gender distribution, so this information is not reported.
- The physical activity level at baseline is not mentioned in the abstract.
- The inclusion/exclusion criteria are not detailed in the abstract.
column20: - "Participants (N = 174, M age = 66.7 years) completed a battery of psychosocial measures at 1 and 5 years following enrollment in a 6-month randomized controlled exercise trial.Results:"
column22:
- The abstract mentions a "6-month randomized controlled exercise trial," which indicates the total intervention period was 6 months.
- The type of physical activity is not specified in the abstract; it only mentions an "exercise trial," which is too general to determine the specific type of physical activity.
- The frequency, duration of each session, and intensity of the physical activity are not mentioned in the abstract.
- Since the abstract does not provide specific details about the type of physical activity, frequency, duration, or intensity, these details are not fully specified.
column23:
- "Participants (N = 174, M age = 66.7 years) completed a battery of psychosocial measures at 1 and 5 years following enrollment in a 6-month randomized controlled exercise trial.Results:"
  - "The findings lend support to the position that physical activity effects on QOL are in part mediated by intermediate psychological outcomes and that physical activity can have long-term effects on well-being."
  - "Analyses indicated that changes in physical activity over the 4-year period were related to increases in physical self-esteem and positive affect, but only positive affect directly influenced improvements in QOL.Conclusions:"
  - "Panel analysis conducted within a covariance modeling framework indicated that physical activity was related to self-efficacy, physical self-esteem, and positive affect at 1 year, and in turn, greater levels of self-efficacy and positive affect were associated with higher levels of QOL."
column25:
- The abstract mentions that participants completed a "battery of psychosocial measures" at 1 and 5 years following enrollment, which suggests that these measures were used to assess various psychological outcomes, including life satisfaction.
- The abstract does not specify the exact tool or instrument used to measure life satisfaction. It only mentions that the measures were part of a "battery of psychosocial measures," which is too vague to identify a specific tool.
- The timing of measurements is mentioned as 1 and 5 years following enrollment, but again, the specific tool or method for measuring life satisfaction is not detailed.
- The abstract does not provide any information on how life satisfaction was quantified, such as the scale or scoring method used.
column26:
- "Analyses indicated that changes in physical activity over the 4-year period were related to increases in physical self-esteem and positive affect, but only positive affect directly influenced improvements in QOL.Conclusions:"
  - "Panel analysis conducted within a covariance modeling framework indicated that physical activity was related to self-efficacy, physical self-esteem, and positive affect at 1 year, and in turn, greater levels of self-efficacy and positive affect were associated with higher levels of QOL."
  - "Physical activity has been effective in enhancing quality of life (QOL) of older adults over relatively short periods of time."
  - "We examined the mediating effects of psychological variables on the relationship between physical activity and global QOL (satisfaction with life) in older adults over a 4-year period.Methods:"
  - "The findings lend support to the position that physical activity effects on QOL are in part mediated by intermediate psychological outcomes and that physical activity can have long-term effects on well-being."
column28:
- The abstract mentions that physical activity enhances quality of life over short periods, but the focus of the study is on long-term effects over a 4-year period.
- The study examines the relationship between physical activity and global QOL, specifically looking at psychological mediators.
- The panel analysis indicates that physical activity is related to psychological variables at 1 year, which in turn are associated with higher QOL levels. This suggests an improvement in life satisfaction at the 1-year mark.
- The abstract does not provide specific statistical significance or magnitude of improvement, nor does it mention exact p-values or effect sizes.
- The study concludes that physical activity has long-term effects on well-being, but again, no specific statistical details are provided.
column29:
- "We examined the mediating effects of psychological variables on the relationship between physical activity and global QOL (satisfaction with life) in older adults over a 4-year period.Methods:"
  - "Participants (N = 174, M age = 66.7 years) completed a battery of psychosocial measures at 1 and 5 years following enrollment in a 6-month randomized controlled exercise trial.Results:"
column31:
- The abstract mentions that participants completed psychosocial measures at 1 and 5 years following enrollment. This indicates that there were follow-up assessments at these two time points.
- The total study follow-up period is explicitly stated as "over a 4-year period," which aligns with the timing of the follow-up assessments (1 year and 5 years after enrollment).
- The initial enrollment period is described as a "6-month randomized controlled exercise trial," but this is not part of the follow-up duration; it is the initial intervention period.
- Therefore, the total study follow-up period is 4 years, with follow-up assessments at 1 year and 5 years after enrollment.

column1: Exercise dose and quality of life: a randomized controlled trial.
column2: C. Martin, T. Church, A. Thompson, C. Earnest, S. Blair
column8: Randomized controlled trial, Intervention study, Longitudinal study
column9:
- Total sample size: 430
- Age range: 45 to 75 years
- Gender distribution: All female
- Physical activity level at baseline: Sedentary (not exercising more than 20 minutes on 3 or more days a week, and < 8000 steps per day)
- Inclusion criteria: Postmenopausal women, sedentary, overweight or obese (BMI 25.0 to 43.0 kg/m^2), elevated systolic blood pressure (120.0 to 159.9 mm Hg)
- Exclusion criteria: History of stroke, heart attack, diabetes, or any medical condition preventing safe exercise; CES-D score ≥10 indicating depression
column10:
- Type of physical activity: Alternating sessions on semi-recumbent cycle ergometers and treadmills
- Frequency: 3 or 4 times per week
- Duration of each session: Not fully specified (total weekly duration: 73.9 minutes for 4 KKW, 138.3 minutes for 8 KKW, 183.6 minutes for 12 KKW)
- Total intervention period: 6 months
- Intensity: Heart rate associated with 50% of each woman's peak VO2
column11:
- Specific tool/instrument used to measure life satisfaction: Medical Outcomes Study Short-Form 36 Health Survey (SF-36)
- Timing of measurements: Baseline and month 6
- How life satisfaction was quantified: Scores converted into a scale from 0 to 100, with higher scores representing better QOL or higher functioning
column12:
- Earliest time point showing statistically significant improvement in life satisfaction: Not explicitly mentioned, but improvements were observed at the end of the 6-month study period.
- Magnitude of improvement: Significant improvements were observed in all physical and mental QOL scales except bodily pain. Quantified improvements include:
  - 12 KKW vs. control: PF 5.7 (1.2-10.2), RP 10.4 (1.3-19.5), GH 6.2 (2.1-10.4), MH 3.6 (0.2-7.1), RE 10.4 (2.3-18.4), SF 9.1 (4.1-14.2), VT 7.1 (1.9-12.2).
  - 4 KKW vs. control: GH 3.9 (0.2-7.6), VT 5.2 (0.5-9.9), SF 4.9 (0.3-9.4), MH 3.8 (0.7-6.9).
  - 8 KKW vs. control: SF 5.4 (0.4-10.4).
- Statistical significance of the change: p-values ranged from <0.0001 to 0.04.
column13:
- Total study follow-up period: 6 months
- Number and timing of follow-up assessments: One follow-up assessment at month 6
column14:
- "The effect of 50%, 100%, and 150% of the physical activity recommendation on QOL was examined in a 6-month randomized controlled trial."
  - "the study was a randomized dose-response exercise trial with a non-exercise control group and three exercise groups with incrementally higher doses of energy expenditure."
  - "Randomization assignment was computer generated and conducted by the statistician."
column16:
- The study is explicitly described as a "6-month randomized controlled trial," which indicates that it is a randomized controlled trial (RCT).
- The study involves randomization, as indicated by "randomization assignment was computer generated and conducted by the statistician," which is a key characteristic of an RCT.
- The study includes a control group and multiple intervention groups, which is typical of an RCT.
- The study is also described as a "dose-response exercise trial," which suggests that it is an intervention study examining the effects of different levels of exercise.
- The study is longitudinal in nature, as it follows participants over a period of six months.
column17:
- "Participants were 430 sedentary postmenopausal women (body mass index range, 25.0-43.0 [calculated as weight in kilograms divided by height in meters squared]) with elevated systolic blood pressure randomized to a nonexercise control group (n = 92) or 1 of 3 exercise groups: exercise energy expenditure of 4 (n = 147), 8 (n = 96), or 12 (n = 95) kilocalories per kilogram of body weight per week."
  - "the study was limited to postmenopausal women age 45 to 75 years who were sedentary (not exercising more than 20 minutes on 3 or more days a week, and < 8000 steps per day assessed over the course of one week), overweight or obese (BMI 25.0 to 43.0 kg/ m 2 ), and who had a systolic blood pressure of 120.0 to 159.9 mm Hg."
  - "Exclusion criteria included history of stroke, heart attack, diabetes, or any medical condition that prevented participants from adhering to the protocol or exercising safely."
  - "Women with a score ≥10 on the Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression scale (CES-D) 15 were excluded based data from our laboratory indicating that these women have a greater probability of attrition and other studies demonstrating that depressed mood is associated with attrition from exercise programs that are part of weight loss programs 16 and cardiac rehabilitation 17"
  - "Participants were recruited from the Dallas, Texas area from April 2001 to June 2005."
  - "A total of 4545 telephone screens were conducted and 4081 potential participants were ineligible based on inclusion and exclusion criteria (Figure 1 ). After giving informed consent, 464 were randomized, of which 432 had complete QOL data at baseline and 398 of these participants completed the study with 356 usable follow-up QOL surveys."
column19:
- The total sample size is explicitly mentioned as 430 participants.
- The age range for participants is specified as 45 to 75 years.
- The gender distribution is entirely female, as the study was limited to postmenopausal women.
- The physical activity level at baseline is described as sedentary, with participants not exercising more than 20 minutes on 3 or more days a week and having fewer than 8000 steps per day.
- Inclusion criteria include being postmenopausal, sedentary, overweight or obese, and having elevated systolic blood pressure.
- Exclusion criteria include a history of stroke, heart attack, diabetes, or any medical condition that prevents safe exercise participation, as well as a high score on the CES-D indicating depression.
column20:
- "Women in the exercise groups alternated training sessions on semi-recumbent cycle ergometers and treadmills."
  - "Exercising women participated in 3 or 4 training sessions each week for 6 months with training intensity at the heart rate associated with 50% of each woman's peak VO 2"
  - "Adherence to exercise was 95.4%, 88.1%, and 93.7% across the 4, 8 and 12 KKW groups and each group spent 73.9, 138.3, and 183.6 minutes per week exercising, respectively"
  - "Adherence to exercise training over the entire 6-month period was calculated for each individual by dividing the kcal expended during the exercise training by the kcal prescribed for the training period multiplied by 100."
column22:
- The study involved three exercise groups with different energy expenditure levels: 4, 8, and 12 kilocalories per kilogram of body weight per week.
- The frequency of exercise sessions was 3 or 4 times per week for all groups.
- The duration of exercise per week varied by group: 73.9 minutes for the 4 KKW group, 138.3 minutes for the 8 KKW group, and 183.6 minutes for the 12 KKW group.
- The total intervention period was 6 months.
- The intensity was specified as being at the heart rate associated with 50% of each woman's peak VO2.
- The type of physical activity involved alternating sessions on semi-recumbent cycle ergometers and treadmills.
column23:
- "Change in QOL was measured with the Medical Outcomes Study Short-Form 36 Health Survey (SF-36)."
  - "Physical QOL is measured with the following four scales: physical functioning (PF), role limitations due to physical problems (Role-Physical or RP), bodily pain (BP), and general health perception (GH)."
  - "Mental QOL also is measured with four scales: role limitations due to emotional problems (Role-Emotional or RE), social functioning (SF), vitality (VT), and mental health (MH)."
  - "Eight aspects of physical and mental QOL were measured at baseline and month 6 with the use of the Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item Short Form Health Survey."
  - "The mean baseline scores for QOL scales for the total population and by group are presented in Table 1"
  - "Figure 3 summarizes the mean change in SF-36 measures across the control and exercise groups."
column25:
- The paper uses the Medical Outcomes Study Short-Form 36 Health Survey (SF-36) to measure quality of life (QOL), which includes both physical and mental aspects.
- The SF-36 is a self-administered questionnaire with 36 items, divided into eight scales that measure different aspects of QOL.
- The scales for physical QOL include physical functioning, role limitations due to physical problems, bodily pain, and general health perception.
- The scales for mental QOL include role limitations due to emotional problems, social functioning, vitality, and mental health.
- The scores from the SF-36 are converted into a scale from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating better QOL or higher functioning.
- Measurements were taken at baseline and at month 6, as indicated by the mention of these time points in the context of using the SF-36.
- The paper does not explicitly mention a specific "Life Satisfaction Measurement" tool, but the SF-36 is used to assess overall QOL, which can be interpreted as related to life satisfaction.
column26:
- "Change in all mental and physical aspects of QOL, except bodily pain, was dose dependent (trend analyses were significant, and exercise dose was a significant predictor of QOL change; P < .05)."
  - "Higher doses of exercise were associated with larger improvements in mental and physical aspects of QOL."
  - "The positive linear trend across groups was statistically significant for all physical and mental QOL scales (all p-values < 0.0001), with exercise dose being a significant independent predictor of change in all QOL scales (p-values ranged from < 0.0001 to 0.04), except bodily pain (p=0. 19)."
  - "The ANCOVAs indicated that for all physical and mental QOL scales, except BP (p=0.32), the 12 KKW group significantly improved QOL compared to the control (p-values ranged from <0.001 to 0.04)."
  - "The primary finding from this randomized controlled exercise trial was a significant, positive dose-response relation between the amount of exercise performed and improvements in measures of both physical and mental QOL."
  - "Though not observed for all measures, it is of interest that even 4 KKW of exercise (approximately 74 min per week) was associated with a significant improvement in QOL for several of the QOL scales as compared with women in the non-exercise control group."
  - "The significant trend (regression) analyses confirm the dose-response effect, however."
  - "Significant trends were found for all QOL scales (all p-values < 0.0001), with exercise dose being an independent predictor of change in PF, t(1) = 3.19, p=0.002; RP, t(1) = 2.62, p=0.009; GH, t(1) = 3.21, p=0.001; MH, t(1) = 2.03, p=0.044; RE, t(1) = 3.00, p=0.003; SF, t(1) = 4.17, p<0.0001; and VT, t(1) = 2.88, p=0.004; but not BP, t(1) = 1.31, p=0.192."
  - "Differences in QOL change across groups were tested by analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with adjustment for pre-specified covariates (age, antidepressant use, BMI, employment status, ethnicity, marital status, and smoking status at baseline)."
  - "Significant ANCOVAs (p < .05) were followed by pairwise comparisons to test if the exercise groups differed significantly from the control group."
  - "The alpha level was set a 0.0167 (.05/3=0.0167) and all p-values were multiplied by three; hence, the following notation was used to depict statistical significance: *p < .05, **p < .01, ***p < .001."
  - "For significant comparisons, the LS mean differences (95% confidence intervals) between the 12 KKW and control group follow: PF 5.7 (1.2-10.2), RP 10.4 (1.3-19.5), GH 6.2 (2.1-10.4), MH 3.6 (0.2-7.1), RE 10.4 (2.3-18.4), SF 9.1 (4.1-14.2), and VT 7.1 (1.9-12.2)."
  - "Similarly, significant LS mean differences (95% CI) between the 4 KKW and control group were: GH 3.9 (0.2-7.6), VT 5.2 (0.5-9.9), SF 4.9 (0.3-9.4), and MH 3.8 (0.7-6.9)."
  - "The 8 KKW significantly improved SF compared to control 5.4 (0.4-10.4)."
column28:
- The study examined the effect of different exercise doses on quality of life (QOL) in sedentary postmenopausal women.
- The results indicate a dose-dependent improvement in QOL, with higher exercise doses associated with larger improvements.
- The study used the Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item Short Form Health Survey (SF-36) to measure QOL.
- Significant improvements were observed in all physical and mental QOL scales except bodily pain.
- The 12 KKW group showed significant improvements compared to the control group in all scales except bodily pain.
- The 4 KKW group also showed significant improvements in some scales compared to the control group.
- The study found a positive linear trend across groups, indicating a dose-response effect.
- The statistical significance of these changes is supported by p-values ranging from <0.0001 to 0.04.
- The magnitude of improvement is quantified with least-squares mean differences and confidence intervals for each scale.
column29:
- "A total of 4545 telephone screens were conducted and 4081 potential participants were ineligible based on inclusion and exclusion criteria (Figure 1 ). After giving informed consent, 464 were randomized, of which 432 had complete QOL data at baseline and 398 of these participants completed the study with 356 usable follow-up QOL surveys."
  - "The effect of 50%, 100%, and 150% of the physical activity recommendation on QOL was examined in a 6-month randomized controlled trial."
  - "Baseline values were carried forward for missing data/drop-outs, resulting in 430 participants' data included in the primary analyses."
column31:
- The study is described as a "6-month randomized controlled trial," which indicates the total study follow-up period.
- The quality of life (QOL) measures were taken at "baseline and month 6," which specifies the timing of the follow-up assessments.
- The study involved a single follow-up assessment at the end of the 6-month period, as indicated by the measurement of QOL at month 6.
- There is no mention of any variation in follow-up periods between participant groups, so the follow-up duration is consistent across all groups.
